skill.name: pyopenms
skill.description: Python interface to OpenMS for mass spectrometry data analysis. Use for LC-MS/MS proteomics and metabolomics workflows including file handling (mzML, mzXML, mzTab, FASTA, pepXML, protXML, mzIdentML), signal processing, feature detection, peptide identification, and quantitative analysis. Apply when working with mass spectrometry data, analyzing proteomics experiments, or processing metabolomics datasets.
skill.summary: Python interface to OpenMS for mass spectrometry data analysis. Use for LC-MS/MS proteomics and meta...
skill.author: davila7

security_audit.summary: This skill consists entirely of documentation and reference guides for the PyOpenMS library. It contains no executable code, scripts, network operations, or file system access beyond what users already have with Python. The skill provides markdown-based guidance for mass spectrometry analysis workflows.

content.user_title: Analyze mass spectrometry data with PyOpenMS
content.value_statement: Mass spectrometry generates complex data that requires specialized tools for proteomics and metabolomics analysis. PyOpenMS provides Python bindings to the OpenMS library, enabling automated processing of LC-MS/MS data, peptide identification, and quantitative analysis with full reproducibility.
actual_capabilities: Read and write mass spectrometry file formats including mzML, mzXML, mzTab, FASTA, and idXML
Apply signal processing algorithms for smoothing, peak picking, normalization, and baseline reduction
Detect features in LC-MS data and link them across multiple samples for quantitative comparison
Perform peptide and protein identification with FDR filtering and protein inference
Execute complete untargeted metabolomics workflows including adduct detection and RT alignment
Export data to pandas DataFrames for integration with statistical analysis tools
limitations: Requires pyopenms package installation which has complex binary dependencies
Does not include search engine executables for peptide identification (Comet, Mascot must be installed separately)
Memory usage scales with data size; very large files require indexed or streaming access patterns
Gap filling and some advanced TOPP tools are not directly accessible through the Python API

use_cases.title: Process LC-MS/MS datasets
use_cases.description: Automate proteomics data processing from raw spectra to protein quantification with reproducible Python scripts

use_cases.title: Untargeted metabolomics analysis
use_cases.description: Detect metabolite features, align retention times across samples, and create quantification tables for statistical analysis

use_cases.title: Integrate MS data with pipelines
use_cases.description: Combine PyOpenMS with pandas, scikit-learn, and other Python tools for custom MS analysis workflows

prompt_templates.title: Load MS data
prompt_templates.prompt: Show me how to load an mzML file with PyOpenMS and access basic spectrum information like MS level, retention time, and peak count

prompt_templates.title: Process spectra
prompt_templates.prompt: Write a PyOpenMS script that applies Gaussian smoothing and peak picking to profile mass spectrometry data

prompt_templates.title: Detect features
prompt_templates.prompt: How do I detect features in centroided LC-MS data using the FeatureFinder and save results to featureXML format

prompt_templates.title: Filter by FDR
prompt_templates.prompt: Demonstrate how to load peptide identification results from idXML, apply 1% FDR filtering, and export filtered results

output_examples.input: Load my sample.mzML file and show me the key statistics
output: MS level distribution (how many MS1 vs MS2 spectra)

best_practices: Use indexed or streaming access for large mzML files to avoid memory issues
Always preserve original data and create copies before processing
Validate file existence and handle exceptions for robust pipelines
anti_patterns: Loading entire very large mzML files into memory without using indexed access
Skipping quality control steps like blank filtering in metabolomics
Applying search parameters without testing tolerance values on a subset first

faq.question: What file formats does PyOpenMS support?
faq.answer: mzML, mzXML, mzData, idXML, mzIdentML, pepXML, protXML, featureXML, consensusXML, mzTab, FASTA, and TraML formats

faq.question: Can I use PyOpenMS on Windows?
faq.answer: Yes, but installation is more complex on Windows. Using conda or WSL is recommended for easier dependency management

faq.question: Does PyOpenMS include search engines?
faq.answer: No, PyOpenMS provides adapters but you must install search engines like Comet, Mascot, or MSGFPlus separately

faq.question: How do I handle very large files?
faq.answer: Use IndexedMzMLFileLoader for random access or MSExperimentConsumer for streaming processing to reduce memory usage

faq.question: Is my data safe with PyOpenMS?
faq.answer: PyOpenMS only processes data locally using the OpenMS library. No data is sent anywhere unless you explicitly code network calls

faq.question: How does PyOpenMS compare to other tools?
faq.answer: PyOpenMS offers Python-native access to a comprehensive C++ algorithms library, combining ease of Python with performance of compiled code
